paragraphs: Want to start a startup? Get funded by Y Combinator. April 2010The best way to come up with startup ideas is to ask yourself the question: what do you wish someone would make for you?There are two types of startup ideas: those that grow organically out of your own life, and those that you decide, from afar, are going to be necessary to some class of users other than you.

Apple was the first type. Apple happened because Steve Wozniak wanted a computer. Unlike most people who wanted computers, he could design one, so he did. And since lots of other people wanted the same thing, Apple was able to sell enough of them to get the company rolling.

They still rely on this principle today, incidentally. The iPhone is the phone Steve Jobs wants. [1]Our own startup, Viaweb, was of the second type. We made software for building online stores. We didn't need this software ourselves.

We weren't direct marketers. We didn't even know when we started that our users were called "direct marketers." But we were comparatively old when we started the company (I was 30 and Robert Morris was 29), so we'd seen enough to know users would need this type of software.

[2]There is no sharp line between the two types of ideas, but the most successful startups seem to be closer to the Apple type than the Viaweb type. When he was writing that first Basic interpreter for the Altair, Bill Gates was writing something he would use, as were Larry and Sergey when they wrote the first versions of Google.Organic ideas are generally preferable to the made up kind, but particularly so when the founders are young.

It takes experience to predict what other people will want. The worst ideas we see at Y Combinator are from young founders making things they think other people will want.So if you want to start a startup and don't know yet what you're going to do, I'd encourage you to focus initially on organic ideas.

What's missing or broken in your daily life? Sometimes if you just ask that question you'll get immediate answers. It must have seemed obviously broken to Bill Gates that you could only program the Altair in machine language.You may need to stand outside yourself a bit to see brokenness, because you tend to get used to it and take it for granted.

You can be sure it's there, though. There are always great ideas sitting right under our noses. In 2004 it was ridiculous that Harvard undergrads were still using a Facebook printed on paper. Surely that sort of thing should have been online.There are ideas that obvious lying around now.

The reason you're overlooking them is the same reason you'd have overlooked the idea of building Facebook in 2004: organic startup ideas usually don't seem like startup ideas at first. We know now that Facebook was very successful, but put yourself back in 2004.

Putting undergraduates' profiles online wouldn't have seemed like much of a startup idea. And in fact, it wasn't initially a startup idea. When Mark spoke at a YC dinner this winter he said he wasn't trying to start a company when he wrote the first version of Facebook.

It was just a project. So was the Apple I when Woz first started working on it. He didn't think he was starting a company. If these guys had thought they were starting companies, they might have been tempted to do something more "serious," and that would have been a mistake.So if you want to come up with organic startup ideas, I'd encourage you to focus more on the idea part and less on the startup part.

Just fix things that seem broken, regardless of whether it seems like the problem is important enough to build a company on. If you keep pursuing such threads it would be hard not to end up making something of value to a lot of people, and when you do, surprise, you've got a company.

[3]Don't be discouraged if what you produce initially is something other people dismiss as a toy. In fact, that's a good sign. That's probably why everyone else has been overlooking the idea. The first microcomputers were dismissed as toys.

And the first planes, and the first cars. At this point, when someone comes to us with something that users like but that we could envision forum trolls dismissing as a toy, it makes us especially likely to invest.While young founders are at a disadvantage when coming up with made-up ideas, they're the best source of organic ones, because they're at the forefront of technology.

They use the latest stuff. They only just decided what to use, so why wouldn't they? And because they use the latest stuff, they're in a position to discover valuable types of fixable brokenness first.There's nothing more valuable than an unmet need that is just becoming fixable.

If you find something broken that you can fix for a lot of people, you've found a gold mine. As with an actual gold mine, you still have to work hard to get the gold out of it. But at least you know where the seam is, and that's the hard part.Notes[1] This suggests a way to predict areas where Apple will be weak: things Steve Jobs doesn't use.

E.g. I doubt he is much into gaming. [2] In retrospect, we should have become direct marketers. If I were doing Viaweb again, I'd open our own online store. If we had, we'd have understood users a lot better.

I'd encourage anyone starting a startup to become one of its users, however unnatural it seems.[3] Possible exception: It's hard to compete directly with open source software. You can build things for programmers, but there has to be some part you can charge for.Thanks to Sam Altman, Trevor Blackwell, and Jessica Livingston for reading drafts of this.

paragraphs.translated:
想创业吗？获得Y Combinator的资助。2010年4月

想出创业点子的最好方法是问自己一个问题：你希望有人为你创造什么？

创业点子有两种：一种是从你自己的生活中有机地产生的，另一种是你从外部决定某些用户群体（而非你自己）需要的东西。

paragraphs.original: Apple was the first type. Apple happened because Steve Wozniak wanted a computer. Unlike most people who wanted computers, he could design one, so he did. And since lots of other people wanted the same thing, Apple was able to sell enough of them to get the company rolling.
paragraphs.translated: 苹果是第一种类型。苹果公司成立是因为史蒂夫·沃兹尼亚克想要一台电脑。与大多数想要电脑的人不同，他能够设计出一台，所以他这么做了。由于许多其他人也有同样的需求，苹果公司能够卖出足够多的电脑，使公司得以起步。

paragraphs.original: They still rely on this principle today, incidentally. The iPhone is the phone Steve Jobs wants. [1]Our own startup, Viaweb, was of the second type. We made software for building online stores. We didn't need this software ourselves.
paragraphs.translated: 他们至今仍然依赖这一原则。iPhone 就是史蒂夫·乔布斯想要的手机。[1]我们自己的初创公司 Viaweb 属于第二种类型。我们开发的是用于构建在线商店的软件。我们自己并不需要这种软件。

paragraphs.original: We weren't direct marketers. We didn't even know when we started that our users were called "direct marketers." But we were comparatively old when we started the company (I was 30 and Robert Morris was 29), so we'd seen enough to know users would need this type of software.
paragraphs.translated: 我们并不是直销营销者。刚开始时，我们甚至不知道我们的用户被称为“直销营销者”。但当我们创办公司时，我们已经算是比较年长了（我30岁，罗伯特·莫里斯29岁），所以我们见过足够多的事情，知道用户需要这种类型的软件。

paragraphs.original: [2]There is no sharp line between the two types of ideas, but the most successful startups seem to be closer to the Apple type than the Viaweb type. When he was writing that first Basic interpreter for the Altair, Bill Gates was writing something he would use, as were Larry and Sergey when they wrote the first versions of Google.Organic ideas are generally preferable to the made up kind, but particularly so when the founders are young.
paragraphs.translated: [2]两者之间的界限并不明显，但最成功的初创公司似乎更接近苹果类型，而非Viaweb类型。当比尔·盖茨为Altair编写第一个Basic解释器时，他编写的是他自己会使用的东西，就像拉里和谢尔盖在编写Google的第一个版本时一样。有机产生的想法通常比人为制造的想法更为可取，尤其是在创始人年轻时更是如此。

paragraphs.original: It takes experience to predict what other people will want. The worst ideas we see at Y Combinator are from young founders making things they think other people will want.So if you want to start a startup and don't know yet what you're going to do, I'd encourage you to focus initially on organic ideas.
paragraphs.translated: 需要经验来预测别人的需求。我们在Y Combinator见到的最糟糕的想法来自年轻的创始人，他们制作他们认为别人会想要的东西。所以，如果你想创业但还不知道自己要做什么，我建议你最初专注于自然产生的想法。

paragraphs.original: What's missing or broken in your daily life? Sometimes if you just ask that question you'll get immediate answers. It must have seemed obviously broken to Bill Gates that you could only program the Altair in machine language.You may need to stand outside yourself a bit to see brokenness, because you tend to get used to it and take it for granted.
paragraphs.translated: 在你的日常生活中，哪些东西缺失或出了问题？有时候，只要你提出这个问题，就能立即得到答案。对比尔·盖茨来说，显然Altair只能用机器语言编程是出了问题。你可能需要稍微站到自己的角度之外，才能看到问题所在，因为人们往往会习惯于这些问题，并将其视为理所当然。

paragraphs.original: You can be sure it's there, though. There are always great ideas sitting right under our noses. In 2004 it was ridiculous that Harvard undergrads were still using a Facebook printed on paper. Surely that sort of thing should have been online.There are ideas that obvious lying around now.
paragraphs.translated: 你可以确信它们就在那里。总有伟大的想法就摆在我们眼前。2004年，哈佛的本科生还在使用纸质的《脸书》目录，这简直荒谬。这种东西显然应该放到网上。现在，肯定也有这样显而易见的想法等待被发现。

paragraphs.original: The reason you're overlooking them is the same reason you'd have overlooked the idea of building Facebook in 2004: organic startup ideas usually don't seem like startup ideas at first. We know now that Facebook was very successful, but put yourself back in 2004.
paragraphs.translated: 你忽视它们的原因和你在2004年会忽视创建Facebook的想法是同一个：有机的创业点子通常一开始并不像创业点子。我们现在知道Facebook非常成功，但请把自己置身于2004年。

paragraphs.original: Putting undergraduates' profiles online wouldn't have seemed like much of a startup idea. And in fact, it wasn't initially a startup idea. When Mark spoke at a YC dinner this winter he said he wasn't trying to start a company when he wrote the first version of Facebook.
paragraphs.translated: 将本科生的资料放到网上似乎并不像一个创业的好主意。实际上，最初这并不是一个创业的想法。当马克在今年冬天的一次YC晚宴上发言时，他说他在编写第一个版本的Facebook时，并没有打算要创办一家公司。

paragraphs.original: It was just a project. So was the Apple I when Woz first started working on it. He didn't think he was starting a company. If these guys had thought they were starting companies, they might have been tempted to do something more "serious," and that would have been a mistake.So if you want to come up with organic startup ideas, I'd encourage you to focus more on the idea part and less on the startup part.
paragraphs.translated: 这只是一个项目。苹果I代也是沃兹最初开始研究时的一个项目。他并没有觉得自己在创办一家公司。如果这些人当时认为自己是在创办公司，他们可能会被诱惑去做一些更“严肃”的事情，那将是一个错误。所以，如果你想提出自然生长的创业点子，我建议你更多地关注点子本身，而不是创业的部分。

paragraphs.original: Just fix things that seem broken, regardless of whether it seems like the problem is important enough to build a company on. If you keep pursuing such threads it would be hard not to end up making something of value to a lot of people, and when you do, surprise, you've got a company.
paragraphs.translated: 只需修复那些看似有问题的事情，不管这个问题是否重要到足以建立一家公司。如果你持续追查这些问题，很难不最终创造出对许多人有价值的东西，而当你做到这一点时，惊喜地发现，你已经拥有一家公司了。

paragraphs.original: [3]Don't be discouraged if what you produce initially is something other people dismiss as a toy. In fact, that's a good sign. That's probably why everyone else has been overlooking the idea. The first microcomputers were dismissed as toys.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你最初的作品被别人当作玩具看待，不要气馁。事实上，这是一个好兆头。这可能正是其他人忽视这个想法的原因。第一台微型计算机就被当作玩具看待。

paragraphs.original: And the first planes, and the first cars. At this point, when someone comes to us with something that users like but that we could envision forum trolls dismissing as a toy, it makes us especially likely to invest.While young founders are at a disadvantage when coming up with made-up ideas, they're the best source of organic ones, because they're at the forefront of technology.
paragraphs.translated: 最早的飞机，最早的汽车。当有人带着用户喜欢但我们可以想象会被论坛喷子贬为玩具的东西来找我们时，我们尤其愿意投资。虽然年轻的创始人在提出虚构的想法时处于劣势，但他们却是有机想法的最佳来源，因为他们站在技术的前沿。

paragraphs.original: They use the latest stuff. They only just decided what to use, so why wouldn't they? And because they use the latest stuff, they're in a position to discover valuable types of fixable brokenness first.There's nothing more valuable than an unmet need that is just becoming fixable.
paragraphs.translated: 他们使用最新的技术。他们刚刚决定要使用什么，所以为什么不呢？由于他们使用最新的技术，他们能够最先发现那些有价值且可修复的问题。没有比刚刚变得可解决的未满足需求更宝贵的东西了。

paragraphs.original: If you find something broken that you can fix for a lot of people, you've found a gold mine. As with an actual gold mine, you still have to work hard to get the gold out of it. But at least you know where the seam is, and that's the hard part.Notes[1] This suggests a way to predict areas where Apple will be weak: things Steve Jobs doesn't use.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你发现了一个可以为很多人解决的问题，那你就找到了一座金矿。就像真正的金矿一样，你仍然需要努力工作才能把金子挖出来。但至少你知道矿脉在哪里，而这已经是很难的部分了。注[1] 这提供了一种预测苹果公司薄弱领域的办法：史蒂夫·乔布斯不使用的东西。

paragraphs.original: E.g. I doubt he is much into gaming. [2] In retrospect, we should have become direct marketers. If I were doing Viaweb again, I'd open our own online store. If we had, we'd have understood users a lot better.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，我怀疑他对游戏并不怎么感兴趣。[2] 回过头来看，我们应该成为直销商。如果我再做一次Viaweb，我会开设我们自己的网上商店。如果我们这样做了，我们会更了解用户。

paragraphs.original: I'd encourage anyone starting a startup to become one of its users, however unnatural it seems.[3] Possible exception: It's hard to compete directly with open source software. You can build things for programmers, but there has to be some part you can charge for.Thanks to Sam Altman, Trevor Blackwell, and Jessica Livingston for reading drafts of this.
paragraphs.translated: 我鼓励任何开始创业的人成为其产品的用户，尽管这看起来可能不太自然。[3] 例外情况：直接与开源软件竞争很难。你可以为程序员开发东西，但必须有一些部分是可以收费的。感谢Sam Altman、Trevor Blackwell和Jessica Livingston阅读本文草稿。
